subject: Re: [junit] Where to place test classes?
msgSnippet: ... Sometimes a class has only one/two public methods, the internal business is split into several smaller (protected) methods (like algorithms).  If you
messageBody:
>>Does anyone have experience using inner classes and
>>JUnit in order to test private methods?


Sometimes a class has only one/two public methods, the internal
"business" is split into several smaller (protected) methods (like
algorithms). If you test your public _and_ protected methods, you're
simply "overtesting" your class (writing more tests than strictly
necessary). It's up to you to decide if you need these tests.

I like the idea of letting the user decide if he/she wants to test the
protected methods or not. Sometimes it's useful, sometimes it's not,
but as I don't know anything about your classes, I prefer not to impose
such rules.

> If your public methods work, doesn't that imply that the
private/protected

> methods also work?


It depends how well these tests cover you class's code. Your test
methods may not cover 100% of the code and your class will still work
fine. If anther class extends this class and calls your
private/protected methods with other arguments (and exercise code you
haven't tested), your class _may_ not work properly anymore.

You can find arguments for not testing public methods and for testing
them. The goal is to find bugs as early as possible (and not to write
tests). If you're confident that you write clean code by only testing
the public methods, fine. Other developers prefer to test public and
protected methods.

It's a matter of confidence
